snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly, PS Now is gonna be hard for Google to beat, when they have such a large library of games you can download to your PS4, even excluding the games they stopped offering on January 2.

However, if Google had a Stadia store where you could buy games, and offered a discount like PS+ does for those who subscribe to Premium, they might catch up. They need a good library, though, and right now they’re nowhere near that level.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: I’m not defending the launch as that was truly awful but I feel this video does a disservice to the platform. I have actively stopped using my PS4 in favour of stadia due to how superior the user experience of buying, playing and experiencing games is. I already have more playable games on stadia than I do on my PS4 due to space limitations. With stadia you never have to worry about storage ever again and every single game you buy is always up to date and always playable FOREVER. That alone is a major reason why I have made the switch. Not to mention the fact that it takes only a few minutes from buying a game to playing it, no downloads or updates. I feel like this review presumes everyone has a $2000 gaming PC and therefore doesn’t even mention the fact that stadia is a fraction of the price at a near similar graphics and performance of one. Plus if you are a Mac user like me this is the answer to PC gaming

snippet.textDisplay: I'm excited about where Stadia will go. I think we'll see a big uptick in Stadia next holiday season because of the new console generation. It doesn't matter how you slice it, the entry price for gaming is expensive. A console and then the game or even more a pc worth running the games and then the games. Stadia has a much lower buy in price, especially when the free version drops and you can use old gamepads you own. Yes, Stadia has its problems but I think it's unique that it is its own ecosystem and it does make games more accessible for more people.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm excited about where Stadia will go. I think we'll see a big uptick in Stadia next holiday season because of the new console generation. Stadia has a much lower buy in price, especially when the free version drops and you can use old gamepads you own. Yes, Stadia has its problems but I think it's unique that it is its own ecosystem and it does make games more accessible for more people.

snippet.textDisplay: I hate how these companies expect every one to be just so willing and able to fork over upwards of 500 dollars for a controller and a tiny selection of games. Playing across screens is easy, just use yee ole VCR in your closet to convert the console signal into an RF signal and connect it to another TV via a long cable. Even a 360's wireless controller has the signal range that will allow you to play from across the house. The real beauty of this method is once the signal leaves the console it is pure analog so you will have ZERO latency issues when playing on the kitchen TV with your game console of choice smouldering in the living room.

snippet.textDisplay: I love my Stadia.  I'm able to play games on my $300 Chromebook and my TV no problem.  This guy probably doesn't know about tech.  I'll answer his question that he can't figure out.  Stadia is the console no more having to buy expensive gaming computers or expensive console.  Just a controller and any screen you are looking at is the monitor.  For $10/month I've gotten 2 free games all of which are more than $10 each plus.  So the $10 subscription is worth it for the free games and extra features.  The free version will be amazing.  Think about it someone who can't afford to buy a powerful computer or a console can game anywhere. 20 years from now you will never have to invest in hardware ever Google is the console

snippet.textDisplay: Google Stadia needs fail hard, so that it gets shut down. It's a con job based on a novelty way of playing that wows the easily impressed. If the games are not up to scratch, you can't blame the devs then sell at full price or you're just a con merchant selling polished turds. The internet will never be good enough, even if you're super rich with a very fast reliable premium ISP. And that's why Stadia doesn't have a market. If you're rich enough to have a very expensive ISP, you're rich enough to buy a PS5 and play in very high quality all the time. If you're poor, the low quality output won't bother you until you realise you can't afford a premium ISP. Never blindly believe the hype. Google are IT wiz kids who entered a market they did not understand. To combat latency they predicted a player action to perform it automatically. That's not gaming.
snippet.textOriginal: Google Stadia needs fail hard, so that it gets shut down. It's a con job based on a novelty way of playing that wows the easily impressed. If you're rich enough to have a very expensive ISP, you're rich enough to buy a PS5 and play in very high quality all the time. If you're poor, the low quality output won't bother you until you realise you can't afford a premium ISP. Never blindly believe the hype. snippet.textDisplay:
They have a problem with the business model. If you are already a gamer you probably have a PC or a Console or both. Stadia might be nice on occasion but you have to buy the game at full price and can only play it on Stadia. To get 4K you need to pay an additional $10 a month. Stadia just does not look that great to existing gamers with this model. I think when the free 1080p service comes out they are going to need a bunch of free to play games to hook existing gamers into the platform.

If you are a new gamer Stadia looks better because of the low cost of entry. You will eventually be able to play for just the cost of the game on a PC or Phone. A set of free to play games would make it much more appealing and might hook these new gamers. I am still not convinced that there is a big pool of people that don't game now and would pick Stadia over a X1 or PS4. I think new gamers are probably going to be brought in by their friends and they will mostly pick what their friends are playing.


I really only see Stadia surviving by being a hub for free to play games. That is the only way I can see them hooking people to the point where they will want to buy from the store.
snippet.textOriginal:
They have a problem with the business model.  If you are already a gamer you probably have a PC or a Console or both.  Stadia might be nice on occasion but you have to buy the game at full price and can only play it on Stadia.  To get 4K you need to pay an additional $10 a month.  Stadia just does not look that great to existing gamers with this model.  I think when the free 1080p service comes out they are going to need a bunch of free to play games to hook existing gamers into the platform.     

If you are a new gamer Stadia looks better because of the low cost of entry.  You will eventually be able to play for just the cost of the game on a PC or Phone.  A set of free to play games would make it much more appealing and might hook these new gamers.  I am still not convinced that there is a big pool of people that don't game now and would pick Stadia over a X1 or PS4.  I think new gamers are probably going to be brought in by their friends and they will mostly pick what their friends are playing.  


I really only see Stadia surviving by being a hub for free to play games.  That is the only way I can see them hooking people to the point where they will want to buy from the store.

snippet.textDisplay:
Here’s a list of things I’d want Google to do. But first, let me put out the hypothetical that they can’t adjust their service so you don’t have to stream the games. Also, I don’t own stadia, this is just what I want google to do to not be a shit company for once. Okay, now the list:

1) at least make a good fiber optic internet service that can work consistently, with no errors or fluctuations in internet speed. (which is possible but we are years away from ever existing)
2) have a decent library of games that I don’t have to pay extra for, because I’m already paying money for the sub service, so why should I have to pay almost full price for the games? That’s not how a streaming service works. Netflix is also a streaming service and you just pay a fee every month for THE ENTIRETY OF NETFLIX!
2.5) also, on that last one, GAMES THAT ACTUALLY RUN AT 4K 60FPS!!!
3) a halfway decent marketing strategy that isn’t just shoving drivel as to “why our shitty service is the best” because, yeah, it is the best BECAUSE NO BODY WANTS INTO THIS MARKET, ESPECIALLY FOR VIDEO GAMES!!!

Also, here’s a little something extra, if changing up the service wasn’t an issue

4) the option to download games so I don’t have to stream them directly from google, and so I can play them offline. This could even cost like ten dollars extra to have, but I’d just want that option, so I wouldn’t mind it.

1) at least make a good fiber optic internet service that can work consistently, with no errors or fluctuations in internet speed. (which is possible but we are years away from ever existing)
2) have a decent library of games that I don’t have to pay extra for, because I’m already paying money for the sub service, so why should I have to pay almost full price for the games? That’s not how a streaming service works. Netflix is also a streaming service and you just pay a fee every month for THE ENTIRETY OF NETFLIX!
2.5) also, on that last one, GAMES THAT ACTUALLY RUN AT 4K 60FPS!!!
3) a halfway decent marketing strategy that isn’t just shoving drivel as to “why our shitty service is the best” because, yeah, it is the best BECAUSE NO BODY WANTS INTO THIS MARKET, ESPECIALLY FOR VIDEO GAMES!!!

Also, here’s a little something extra, if changing up the service wasn’t an issue

4) the option to download games so I don’t have to stream them directly from google, and so I can play them offline. This could even cost like ten dollars extra to have, but I’d just want that option, so I wouldn’t mind it.

snippet.textDisplay: Ummmmm, no Google. It’s not the ISP’s job to ensure their service is enough to run your products in a stable manner. No it’s not game developers jobs to spend money and resources to optimise their games for the tiny, tiny Stadia user base. The cheek of Google to sell a beta product, lie about its capabilities and then blame everything else is galling.
snippet.textOriginal: Ummmmm, no Google. It’s not the ISP’s job to ensure their service is enough to run your products in a stable manner. No it’s not game developers jobs to spend money and resources to optimise their games for the tiny, tiny Stadia user base. The cheek of Google to sell a beta product, lie about its capabilities and then blame everything else is galling.

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't understand the uproar in regards to the subscription model.
Stadia is a public cloud hosted Software-as-a-Service offering by Google with a subscription being equal to a flatrate on Google Cloud Platform (utilizing computing resources and data traffic going out of the datacenter). (EDIT: If we we're to built a Stadia Clone on Google Cloud Platform,) we can assume just the infrastructure cost to be at least 0.23 USD/hour (EDIT: It's actually a lot higher when it comes to 4K streaming), which breaks even after just 43 hours of usage at a 10USD/month subscription plan. The subscription only pays for the infrastructure and platform, not the games. There is no comparable streaming model like Spotify for Games and I do not think that Google ever tried to establish this.
snippet.textOriginal:
I don't understand the uproar in regards to the subscription model.

(EDIT: If we we're to built a Stadia Clone on Google Cloud Platform,) we can assume just the infrastructure cost to be at least 0.23 USD/hour (EDIT: It's actually a lot higher when it comes to 4K streaming), which breaks even after just 43 hours of usage at a 10USD/month subscription plan. The subscription only pays for the infrastructure and platform, not the games. There is no comparable streaming model like Spotify for Games and I do not think that Google ever tried to establish this.

snippet.textDisplay: I hope more people realize Stadia and other streaming services (games AND movies) are bad from a long term consumer standpoint, imagine for a second you are living 40, or even 20 years from now, you can still plug a copy of Super Mario Bros. 3 into your NES, but can you guarantee you'll be able to play it on the Switch then? And what about new games that pulled and essentially vanish? This has already happened numerous times on Android and IOS (and that's not even streaming). I would personally love to see a day when someone makes a Video Game Console that you can plug a cartridge or disc into 10, 20, 50 or even 100 years down the road and still have it to work the same as on day 1.
snippet.textOriginal: I hope more people realize Stadia and other streaming services (games AND movies) are bad from a long term consumer standpoint, imagine for a second you are living 40, or even 20 years from now, you can still plug a copy of Super Mario Bros. 3 into your NES, but can you guarantee you'll be able to play it on the Switch then? And what about new games that pulled and essentially vanish? This has already happened numerous times on Android and IOS (and that's not even streaming). I would personally love to see a day when someone makes a Video Game Console that you can plug a cartridge or disc into 10, 20, 50 or even 100 years down the road and still have it to work the same as on day 1.

- A more netflix type of subscription model where I pay a monthly fee and have access to the whole library.

Safe to say I'll never be getting Stadia.

snippet.textDisplay: I'd pay the 10 bucks a month if I could play the games I already digitally own on other platforms. Ain't like google would benefit with money in that way anyways, but it would get more talk and more people would be intrigued.

snippet.textDisplay: I guess I’m in the minority, but I personally love Stadia. Performance has been solid. The platform flexibility is great. I can’t wait to see what Google does with it, assuming they don’t axe it in the next several years or so.
snippet.textOriginal: I guess I’m in the minority, but I personally love Stadia. Performance has been solid. The platform flexibility is great. I can’t wait to see what Google does with it, assuming they don’t axe it in the next several years or so.

snippet.textDisplay: If it can stream next gen titles on the free service at the same detail as a ps5 or Xbox x next Christmas I think it could find an audience. I've been enjoying streaming on psnow so I'm happy to stream games if I can't play them otherwise and I'd probably need a hefty upgrade to play next gen titles properly so could be a useful stopgap. Plus they need a library of games for subscribers even if it's only older titles.

snippet.textDisplay: The only way I would get Google Stadia is if they implement this touch to play.  If you could play with maybe your favorite streamer without owning the game.   Maybe only the streamer needs to own it for some people to play with him/her.  There are still lots of players that maybe can't afford a $50 game.  If stadia would make its own streaming service like twitch, mixer, or youtube gaming.  This way someone could hop on the stream and play with the streamer.  Games like the Madden franchise would implement very well in this sircumstance.
snippet.textOriginal: The only way I would get Google Stadia is if they implement this touch to play.  If you could play with maybe your favorite streamer without owning the game.   Maybe only the streamer needs to own it for some people to play with him/her.  There are still lots of players that maybe can't afford a $50 game.  If stadia would make its own streaming service like twitch, mixer, or youtube gaming.  This way someone could hop on the stream and play with the streamer.
